004
005package edu.wpi.first.math.controller;
006
007/**
008 * A helper class that computes feedforward outputs for a simple arm (modeled as a motor acting
009 * against the force of gravity on a beam suspended at an angle).
010 */
011@SuppressWarnings("MemberName")
012public class ArmFeedforward {
013  public final double ks;
014  public final double kcos;
015  public final double kv;
016  public final double ka;
017
018  /**
019   * Creates a new ArmFeedforward with the specified gains. Units of the gain values will dictate
020   * units of the computed feedforward.
021   *
022   * @param ks The static gain.
023   * @param kcos The gravity gain.
024   * @param kv The velocity gain.
025   * @param ka The acceleration gain.
026   */
027  public ArmFeedforward(double ks, double kcos, double kv, double ka) {
028    this.ks = ks;
029    this.kcos = kcos;
030    this.kv = kv;
031    this.ka = ka;
032  }
033
034  /**
035   * Creates a new ArmFeedforward with the specified gains. Acceleration gain is defaulted to zero.
036   * Units of the gain values will dictate units of the computed feedforward.
037   *
038   * @param ks The static gain.
039   * @param kcos The gravity gain.
040   * @param kv The velocity gain.
041   */
042  public ArmFeedforward(double ks, double kcos, double kv) {
043    this(ks, kcos, kv, 0);
044  }
045
046  /**
047   * Calculates the feedforward from the gains and setpoints.
048   *
049   * @param positionRadians The position (angle) setpoint. This angle should be measured from the
050   *     horizontal (i.e. if the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel with the floor). If
051   *     your encoder does not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
052   * @param velocityRadPerSec The velocity setpoint.
053   * @param accelRadPerSecSquared The acceleration setpoint.
054   * @return The computed feedforward.
055   */
056  public double calculate(
057      double positionRadians, double velocityRadPerSec, double accelRadPerSecSquared) {
058    return ks * Math.signum(velocityRadPerSec)
059        + kcos * Math.cos(positionRadians)
060        + kv * velocityRadPerSec
061        + ka * accelRadPerSecSquared;
062  }
063
064  /**
065   * Calculates the feedforward from the gains and velocity setpoint (acceleration is assumed to be
066   * zero).
067   *
068   * @param positionRadians The position (angle) setpoint. This angle should be measured from the
069   *     horizontal (i.e. if the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel with the floor). If
070   *     your encoder does not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
071   * @param velocity The velocity setpoint.
072   * @return The computed feedforward.
073   */
074  public double calculate(double positionRadians, double velocity) {
075    return calculate(positionRadians, velocity, 0);
076  }
077
078  // Rearranging the main equation from the calculate() method yields the
079  // formulas for the methods below:
080
081  /**
082   * Calculates the maximum achievable velocity given a maximum voltage supply, a position, and an
083   * acceleration. Useful for ensuring that velocity and acceleration constraints for a trapezoidal
084   * profile are simultaneously achievable - enter the acceleration constraint, and this will give
085   * you a simultaneously-achievable velocity constraint.
086   *
087   * @param maxVoltage The maximum voltage that can be supplied to the arm.
088   * @param angle The angle of the arm. This angle should be measured from the horizontal (i.e. if
089   *     the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel with the floor). If your encoder does
090   *     not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
091   * @param acceleration The acceleration of the arm.
092   * @return The maximum possible velocity at the given acceleration and angle.
093   */
094  public double maxAchievableVelocity(double maxVoltage, double angle, double acceleration) {
095    // Assume max velocity is positive
096    return (maxVoltage - ks - Math.cos(angle) * kcos - acceleration * ka) / kv;
097  }
098
099  /**
100   * Calculates the minimum achievable velocity given a maximum voltage supply, a position, and an
101   * acceleration. Useful for ensuring that velocity and acceleration constraints for a trapezoidal
102   * profile are simultaneously achievable - enter the acceleration constraint, and this will give
103   * you a simultaneously-achievable velocity constraint.
104   *
105   * @param maxVoltage The maximum voltage that can be supplied to the arm.
106   * @param angle The angle of the arm. This angle should be measured from the horizontal (i.e. if
107   *     the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel with the floor). If your encoder does
108   *     not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
109   * @param acceleration The acceleration of the arm.
110   * @return The minimum possible velocity at the given acceleration and angle.
111   */
112  public double minAchievableVelocity(double maxVoltage, double angle, double acceleration) {
113    // Assume min velocity is negative, ks flips sign
114    return (-maxVoltage + ks - Math.cos(angle) * kcos - acceleration * ka) / kv;
115  }
116
117  /**
118   * Calculates the maximum achievable acceleration given a maximum voltage supply, a position, and
119   * a velocity. Useful for ensuring that velocity and acceleration constraints for a trapezoidal
120   * profile are simultaneously achievable - enter the velocity constraint, and this will give you a
121   * simultaneously-achievable acceleration constraint.
122   *
123   * @param maxVoltage The maximum voltage that can be supplied to the arm.
124   * @param angle The angle of the arm. This angle should be measured from the horizontal (i.e. if
125   *     the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel with the floor). If your encoder does
126   *     not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
127   * @param velocity The velocity of the arm.
128   * @return The maximum possible acceleration at the given velocity.
129   */
130  public double maxAchievableAcceleration(double maxVoltage, double angle, double velocity) {
131    return (maxVoltage - ks * Math.signum(velocity) - Math.cos(angle) * kcos - velocity * kv) / ka;
132  }
133
134  /**
135   * Calculates the minimum achievable acceleration given a maximum voltage supply, a position, and
136   * a velocity. Useful for ensuring that velocity and acceleration constraints for a trapezoidal
137   * profile are simultaneously achievable - enter the velocity constraint, and this will give you a
138   * simultaneously-achievable acceleration constraint.
139   *
140   * @param maxVoltage The maximum voltage that can be supplied to the arm.
141   * @param angle The angle of the arm. This angle should be measured from the horizontal (i.e. if
142   *     the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel with the floor). If your encoder does
143   *     not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
144   * @param velocity The velocity of the arm.
145   * @return The minimum possible acceleration at the given velocity.
146   */
147  public double minAchievableAcceleration(double maxVoltage, double angle, double velocity) {
148    return maxAchievableAcceleration(-maxVoltage, angle, velocity);
149  }
150}
